questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the outreach and impact of a social marketing program aimed at improving contraceptive use in a low-resource setting. The program involves the distribution of family planning commodities through commercial but subsidized channels to make them accessible and affordable to the target population.  Which of the following contraceptive devices is typically supplied under a social marketing program?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Condom

 

Option B:

 

Condoms are manufactured in India by the Hindustan Latex in Trivandrum, London Rubber Industries in Chennai, and others. Besides commercial outlets, condoms are supplied under the social marketing program under the brand name of NIRODH.

 

Social Marketing

 

Concept: Seeks to develop and integrate marketing concepts with other approaches to influence behaviors that benefit individuals and communities for the greater social good. Social marketing seeks to influence social behaviors not to benefit the marketer, but to benefit the target audience and the general society. 

 

Example: Installation of Condom vending machines (CVM)s) at parks, pay and use toilets, railway stations, bus stations, petrol pumps, wine shops, bars, restaurants, STD/PCO booths, tea-shops, paan-shops

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Intra uterine Devices, C. Diaphragm, & D. Vaginal Sponge are not supplied under social marketing. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condoms are supplied under the social marketing program through Condom vending machines (CVMs) at parks, pay and use toilets, railway stations, bus stations, petrol pumps, wine shops, bars, restaurants, STD/PCO booths, tea-shops, paan-shops

 

Ref: Park 26th ed, pg 575

questions.text: In the family welfare outpatient department, a survey is conducted to evaluate the side effects and complications associated with intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUDs). The survey aims to identify the primary reasons for the removal of IUDs among users to enhance counseling and management strategies. Which of the following complications is most commonly associated with the removal of intrauterine devices (IUDs)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pain

 

Option A:

 

The commonest complaint of women fitted with an IUD is increased vaginal bleeding. It accounts for 10-20 percent of all IUD removals.  Pain is the second major side-effect leading to IUD removal. WHO estimates that 15-40 percent of IUD removals appear to be for pain only. Pain may be experienced during IUD insertion and for a few days thereafter, as well as during menstruation. It may manifest itself in low backache, cramps in the lower abdomen and occasionally pain down the thighs.

 

Pain:

 

  • Second major side effect of IUD insertion
  • MCC requiring removal of IUDs: Pain (15–40% removals)
  • Usually disappear by: 3 months
  • Pain is more common in - Nullipara, those who have not had child for many years,
  • Management of Pain:
    • Slight pain: Analgesics like Aspirin or Codeine
    • Intolerable pain: Remove the IUD, insert a copper based device or advise other contraceptives

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bleeding:

 

  • MC side effect of woman with IUD: Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Usually disappear by: 1–2 months
  • Leads to: 10–20% of all IUD removals (MCC removal: Pain)
  • Greater bleeding with: Non-medicated (Inert) IUDs
  • Management of bleeding:
    • Re-assure the female (DO NOT REMOVE IUD)
    • Ferrous sulphate 200 mg TDS X 1–2 months
    • If bleeding is heavy or persistent: REMOVE IUD

 

Option C. Pelvic infection:  (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease)

 

  • Prompt treatment with broad spectrum antibiotics
  • If no response to antibiotics in 24–48 hours: Remove IUD

                

Option D. Uterine perforation:  Management: Removal of IUD

 

Educational Objective:

 

MC side effect of woman with IUD: Increased vaginal bleeding

 

MCC requiring removal of IUDs: Pain (15–40% removals)

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 578

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of mild hypertension is seeking advice on contraceptive options. She expresses a desire for natural family planning methods due to concerns about the side effects of hormonal contraception. During your discussion, you explore various natural contraceptive methods and also consider one option that does not align with natural family planning strategies.

 

Which of the following is NOT considered a natural contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral Contraceptive Pills

 

Option B:

 

Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) are not considered a natural method of contraception. They are a form of hormonal contraception that typically contains synthetic forms of estrogen and progesterone, which work by preventing ovulation, thickening cervical mucus to block sperm, and altering the uterine lining to prevent implantation of a fertilized egg. Natural contraceptive methods, on the other hand, rely on awareness of the body's fertility signals without the use of pharmaceuticals or physical devices. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Basal Body temperature: At the time of ovulation, basal body temperature increases by 0.3 to 0.5 degree Celsius; Occurs due to increased progesterone production; Measure temperature before getting out of bed in morning (preferably)

 

Option C. Billing method: Cervical mucus thickening / Ovulation method - At the time of ovulation, cervical mucus becomes watery clear resembling raw egg white, smooth, slippery, and profuse. After ovulation, under the influence of progesterone, the mucus thickens and lessens in quantity.

 

Option D. Symptothermic method: Combination of BBT+Calender+ Billing method.

 

Other Natural contraceptive method includes:

 

  1. Sexual abstinence – Only method of birth control which is completely effective
  2. Coitus interruptus/Withdrawal method – Oldest method of voluntary fertility control
  3. Lactation amenorrhoea method (LAM): A good method for natural conception under exclusive breast feeding

 

Educational Objective:

 

Only method of birth control which is completely effective: Sexual abstinence

 

Oldest method of voluntary fertility control: Coitus interruptus

 

Fertile period: Shortest cycle minus 18 days (Last day of fertile period: Longest cycle minus 10 days); High failure rate (9 per HWY)

 

BBT Method - Rise of temperature (0.3°–0.5°C) at ovulation

 

Ref: Park 26th ed pg 588.
